quest_title: Consider three long straight, parallel wires shown in figure. The force experienced by 25 cm length of wire '\({C}\)' is
explanation_txt:
Force on \(25 \mathrm{cm}\) long wire \(\mathrm{C}\) due to \(\mathrm{A}\) is

\(F_{C A}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cfrac{2 I_{A} \times I_{C}}{3 \times 10^{-2}} \times \cfrac{25}{100} \text { towards right } \)

\(F_{C A}=10^{-7} \times \cfrac{2 \times 30 \times 20 \times 25}{3}=5 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{N} \)

Force on \(25 \mathrm{cm}\) long wire \(\mathrm{C}\) due to \(\mathrm{B}\) is

\(F_{C B}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \cfrac{2 I_{B} \times I_{C}}{5 \times 10^{-2}} \times \cfrac{25}{100} \text { towards left } \)

\(F_{CB }=10^{-7} \times \cfrac{2 \times 10 \times 20 \times 25}{5}=2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{N} \)

\(\text { Net force } F=\left(F_{C A}-F_{C B}\right) \text { towards right } \)

\(\text { Net force } F=3 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{N} \text { towards right. } \)
question_plain_title: Consider three long straight, parallel wires shown in figure. The force experienced by 25 cm length of wire '' is
explanation_plain_text:
Force on long wire due to is

Force on long wire due to is
ans1_plain_text: 1 10N towards right
ans2_plain_text: 3 10N towards left
ans3_plain_text: 3 10N towards right
ans4_plain_text: 2 10N towards left

quest_title: At a place the angle of dip is 30\(^\circ\). If the horizontal component of earth's magnetic field is \(\text{H}\), then total field intensity is
explanation_txt:
We know that, \(B_{H}=B \cos \delta\)
\(\therefore B=\cfrac{B_{H}}{\cos \delta}=\cfrac{H}{\cos 30^{\circ}}=\cfrac{2 H}{\sqrt{3}}\)

quest_title: \(\begin{array} { l } { p H \text { of a solution of } 10 \mathrm { ml } .1 N \text { sodium acetate and } 50 \mathrm { ml } \text { 2N } } \\ { \text { acetic acid } \left( K _ { a } = 1.8 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \right) , \text { is approximately } } \end{array}\)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { p H = p K _ { a } + \log \cfrac { [ \text { Salt } ] } { [ \text { Acid } ] } } \\ { p H = - \log \left( 1.8 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \right) + \log \cfrac { [ 10 ] } { [ 100 ] } } \\ { = - \log 1.8 + 5 + \log 10 ^ { - 1 } } \\ { = - 0.2553 + 5 - 1 = 3.7447 \quad \text { or } = 4 } \end{array}\)

quest_title: A block of mass 20 kg is placed on a rough table. The coefficient of static and kinetic frictions between block and table are 0.4 & 0.3 respectively. A horizontal force of 100 N is applied on block, then frictional force will be
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \text { Limiting force of friction }\left(F_{f}\right) &=\mu_{s} R \\ &=0.4 \times m g \\&=0.4 \times 200 \\ &= 80 \, N \end{aligned}\)

Applied force \((F)=100 \mathrm{N}\)
Body comes in motion \(\mathrm{so}\)
Frictional force \(\left(F_{k}\right)=\mu_{k} m g\)
\(\qquad=0.3 \times 200=60 \mathrm{N}\)

quest_title: When a copper ball is heated, the largest percentage increase will occur in its
explanation_txt: When a copper ball is heated, it's size increases. As Volume \(\propto (\) radius) \(^ { 3 }\) and Area \(\propto (\) radius \() ^ { 2 } ,\) so percentage increase will be largest in its volume. Density will decrease with rise in temperature.

quest_title: A carnot engine working between 27\({}^{0}\)c and 100\({}^{0}\)c absorbs 1000 calories of heat in each cycle. The amount of heat rejected is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Q}_{1}=& 1000 \text { calorie } \\ \eta=& \cfrac{w}{Q_{1}}=1-\cfrac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} \\ \text { Or, } w &=\left(1-\cfrac{300}{373}\right) 1000 \\ &=196 \text { calorie } \\ \therefore Q_{2} &=Q_{1}-w=1000-196=804 \mathrm{cal} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: Due to flow of current in a circular loop of radius \({R}\), the magnetic induction produced at centre of the loop is \({(B)}\) The magnetic moment of the loop is \(\mu_0\) = permeability constant)
explanation_txt:
The magnetic induction at the centre is given by
\(B=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i}{2 R}\)
The magnetic moment is \(P_{m}=i A=i \pi R^{2} \)
\(P_{m}=\left(\cfrac{B 2 R}{\mu_{0}}\right) \times \pi R^{2}\)
\(P_{m}=\cfrac{2 \pi B R^{3}}{\mu_{0}} \)

quest_title: The inductance of a solenoid is 5 H and its resistance is 5 \(\Omega\). If it is connected to 10 V battery then time taken by the current to reach 9/10 of the maximum value will be
explanation_txt:
\(\text { For } L-R \text { circuit } \)
\(\begin{aligned} i=& i_{0}\left(1-e^{-t/\tau}\right) ; \text { where } \tau=\cfrac{L}{R} \\ \cfrac{i}{i_{0}} &=\left(1-e^{-t}\right) \\ \Rightarrow & \cfrac{9}{10}=1-e^{-t} \quad \Rightarrow e^{-t}=\cfrac{1}{10} \\ \therefore e^{t} &=10 \\ \therefore t &=\log _{e}^{10}=2.3 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: The inductance of a solenoid is 5 H and its resistance is 5 . If it is connected to 10 V battery then time taken by the current to reach 9/10 of the maximum value will be

quest_title: A magnetizing field of 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{3}\) amp/m produces a magnetic flux density 8\(\text{\(\pi\)}\) tesla in an iron rod. The relative permeability of the rod will be
explanation_txt: \begin{array}{l}{\text { We lanow that, }} \\ {\qquad \begin{aligned} \mu_{r}=& \cfrac{\mu }{\mu_{0}}=\cfrac{\mu H}{\mu_{0} H}=\cfrac{B}{\mu_{0} H} \\ &=\cfrac{8 \pi}{\left(4 \pi \times 10^{-7}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{3}\right)} \\ &=10^{4} \end{aligned}}\end{array}

quest_title: For the reaction A(g) + B (g) \(\leftrightharpoons\) C (g) the equilibrium partial pressure are : \(\text{P\(_{A}\)}\) = 0.15 atm \(\text{P\(_{B}\)}\) = 0.10 atm and \(\text{P\(_{C}\)}\) = 0.30 atm. Tthe volume of the reaction vessel was reduced so that on reestablishing the equilibrium the partial pressures of A and B are doubled the partial pressure of C would be
explanation_txt:
Given:

\(\begin{matrix} &A &+& B &\rightleftharpoons & C \\ p_0: &0.15 &&0.1&&0.30 \\ p: &0.3 && 0.2 && x \end{matrix}\)

Since in both states, equilibrium was maintained, \(k_p\) remains unchanged.

\( \cfrac{0.3}{0.15 \times 0.1} = \cfrac{x}{0.3 \times 0.2} \\ \Rightarrow x=1.2\)
question_plain_title: For the reaction A(g) + B (g) C (g) the equilibrium partial pressure are : = 0.15 atm = 0.10 atm and = 0.30 atm. Tthe volume of the reaction vessel was reduced so that on reestablishing the equilibrium the partial pressures of A and B are doubled the partial pressure of C would be
explanation_plain_text:
Given:

Since in both states, equilibrium was maintained, remains unchanged.

quest_title: Which of the following can not exist on the basis of MO Theory?
explanation_txt:
According to molecular orbital theory He2 has 2 electrons in sigma 1s bonding and 2 in sigma 1s antibonding.

So, bond order = half the difference in the numbers of bonding and antibonding electrons = 0

But, bond order must be at least one, which concludes He2 molecule has no existence.
question_plain_title: Which of the following can not exist on the basis of MO Theory?
explanation_plain_text:
According to molecular orbital theory He2 has 2 electrons in sigma 1s bonding and 2 in sigma 1s antibonding.

But, bond order must be at least one, which concludes He2 molecule has no existence.

quest_title: The ionization energy of hydrogen is 13.6 eV. The energy required to excite the electron in singly ionized helium atom (He\({}^{+}\)) from first to second orbit is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{E}_{1}=-13.6 \mathrm{eV}\)
For Helium
\(\mathrm{E}=\left\{\cfrac{-13.6 \times \mathrm{Z}^{2}}{2^{2}}-\left(-\cfrac{13.6 \mathrm{Z}^{2}}{1^{2}}\right)\right\}\)
\(\quad=4(13.6-3.4)=40.8 \mathrm{eV}\)

quest_title: The final product obtained on strong heating of copper nitrate is:
explanation_txt:
When copper nitrate is heated, it loses the water molecule first, and on further heating it decomposes to give reddish brown gas, nitrogen dioxide and oxygen.

Chemically,

\( Cu(NO_3)_2 \cdot 3H_2O \xrightarrow[]{\Delta} Cu(NO_3)_2 + 3H_2O \\ \underset{\text{Copper nitrate}}{2Cu(NO_3)_2} \xrightarrow[]{\Delta} \underset{\text{Copper oxide}}{2CuO} + 4NO_2 + O_2 \)
question_plain_title: The final product obtained on strong heating of copper nitrate is:
explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: A physical parameter a can be determined by measuring the parameters b, c, d and e using the relation \(a=\cfrac{b ^ { \alpha } c ^ { \beta }}{d ^ { \gamma } e ^ { \delta }}\). If the maximum errors in the measurement of b, c, d and e are \(b _ { 1 } \% , c _ { 1 } \% , d _ { 1 } \%\) and \(e _ { 1 } \%\), then the maximum error in the value of a determined by the experiment is
explanation_txt:
\(a = \cfrac{b ^ { \alpha } c ^ { \beta }}{d ^ { \gamma } e ^ { \delta }}\)

So maximum error in a is given by

\(\left( \cfrac { \Delta a } { a } \times 100 \right) _ { \max } = \alpha \cdot \cfrac { \Delta b } { b } \times 100 + \beta \cdot \cfrac { \Delta c } { c } \times 100 + \gamma \cdot \cfrac { \Delta d } { d } \times 100 + \delta \cdot \cfrac { \Delta e } { e } \times 100\)

\(= \left( \alpha b _ { 1 } + \beta c _ { 1 } + \gamma d _ { 1 } + \delta e _ { 1 } \right) \%\)

quest_title: A boat crosses a river with a velocity of 8 km/h. If the resulting velocity of boat is 10 km/h then the velocity of river water is
explanation_txt:
From the figure,

\(\begin{array} { l } { \vec { v _ { b r } } = \vec { v _ { b } } + \vec { v _ { r } } } \\ { \Rightarrow v _ { b r } = \sqrt { v _ { b } ^ { 2 } + v _ { r } ^ { 2 } } } \\ { \Rightarrow 10 = \sqrt { 8 ^ { 2 } + v _ { r } ^ { 2 } } } \end{array}\)

\(\Rightarrow v _ { r } = 6 k m / h r\)

quest_title: A man standing on weighing machine placed in a lift. When the lift is stationary then weight is recorded 40 kg. If the lift is accelerated upward with an acceleration of 2 m/s\({}^{2}\) then weight recorded will be
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)\(R\) = \(mg\) = 40 kg wt.

\(\quad\)\(R\) - \(mg\) = \(ma\)

\(R\) = \(mg\) + \(ma\) = 40 (10 + 2) = 480 N

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\) = 48 kg wt.
question_plain_title: A man standing on weighing machine placed in a lift. When the lift is stationary then weight is recorded 40 kg. If the lift is accelerated upward with an acceleration of 2 m/s then weight recorded will be
explanation_plain_text:
= = 40 kg wt.

- =

= + = 40 (10 + 2) = 480 N

= 48 kg wt.
